Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260, \u00a7 2A.proposition: (Selected statutes, rules, and authorities commonly relied on in Massachusetts negligence cases; provided for reference and judicial context)

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 140 \u00a7\u00a7 136.proposition: (Selected statutes, rules, and authorities commonly relied on in Massachusetts negligence cases; provided for reference and judicial context)

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: (Selected statutes, rules, and authorities commonly relied on in Massachusetts negligence cases; provided for reference and judicial context)

Brown v. Kendall, 60 Mass. 292 (1850).proposition: Representative Massachusetts and other leading cases on negligence principles (illustrative; not an exhaustive list)
Brown v. Kendall, 60 Mass. 292 (1850).support_reasoning: The opinion is a foundational negligence case that clearly articulates core negligence principles: duty of ordinary care under the circumstances, no liability for purely accidental harm in the course of a lawful act, contributory negligence, and allocation of the burden of proving lack of due care. These features make Brown v. Kendall a leading Massachusetts authority frequently cited as representative of general negligence doctrine, so using it illustratively for that proposition is accurate.
Brown v. Kendall, 60 Mass. 292 (1850).relevant_excerpt: “We think, as the result of all the authorities, the rule is correctly stated by Mr. Greenleaf, that the plaintiff must come prepared with evidence to show either that the intention was unlawful, or that the defendant was in fault; for if the injury was unavoidable, and the conduct of the defendant was free from blame, he will not be liable… if it appears that the defendant was doing a lawful act, and unintentionally hit and hurt the plaintiff, then unless it also appears… that the defendant is chargeable with some fault… the plaintiff… is not entitled to recover.”

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: Representative Massachusetts and other leading cases on negligence principles (illustrative; not an exhaustive list)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: The proposition describes Palsgraf as a “representative Massachusetts and other leading case[] on negligence principles,” which is inaccurate. Palsgraf is a leading New York Court of Appeals decision and is not a Massachusetts case, nor is it cited here as representative of Massachusetts doctrine. While it is indeed a leading case on negligence and duty, it does not support being characterized as a Massachusetts authority, so it does not support the proposition as phrased.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “Negligence is not actionable unless it involves the invasion of a legally protected interest, the violation of a right… ‘In every instance, before negligence can be predicated of a given act, back of the act must be sought and found a duty to the individual complaining, the observance of which would have averted or avoided the injury’… ‘The ideas of negligence and duty are strictly correlative.’”

DiPietro v. Nat\u2019l Super Mkts., 372.raw_text: DiPietro v. Nat’l Super Mkts., 372 Mass. 101 (1977)
DiPietro v. Nat\u2019l Super Mkts., 372.proposition: Representative Massachusetts and other leading cases on negligence principles (illustrative; not an exhaustive list)
DiPietro v. Nat\u2019l Super Mkts., 372.support_reasoning: The proposition describes the case as a representative Massachusetts (and other leading) decision on negligence principles. This opinion does not concern negligence at all; it deals with the scope and procedure of G.L. c. 93A §11 and with fraudulent conveyance under G.L. c. 109A, plus Rule 12(b)(6) pleading standards. It therefore does not support a proposition about negligence principles and would be a miscitation in that context.
DiPietro v. Nat\u2019l Super Mkts., 372.relevant_excerpt: “This case presents questions about the scope of G. L. c. 93A, § 11, which gives a private cause of action to a person who is engaged in business and who suffers a loss as a result of an unfair or deceptive act or practice by another person also engaged in business… These motions to dismiss present the question of the legal sufficiency of the complaint as stating claims under G. L. c. 93A, § 11, and G. L. c. 109A, §§ 4, 7.”

Roy v. Commonwealth, 436 Mass. 1 (2002).proposition: Representative Massachusetts and other leading cases on negligence principles (illustrative; not an exhaustive list)
Roy v. Commonwealth, 436 Mass. 1 (2002).support_reasoning: This decision is a criminal procedure/search-and-seizure case about the scope of search warrants, the plain view doctrine (including inadvertence under art. 14), and the exclusionary rule. It does not discuss negligence, duty, breach, causation, or any tort-law negligence principles. Therefore it cannot be considered a representative Massachusetts or leading case on negligence principles.
Roy v. Commonwealth, 436 Mass. 1 (2002).relevant_excerpt: "Searches and seizures conducted outside of the scope of a valid warrant are presumed to be unreasonable. Commonwealth v. Antobenedetto, 366 Mass. 51, 57 (1974). When a search or seizure is conducted outside of the scope of a warrant, the burden is on the Commonwealth to demonstrate that the activity falls within an exception to the warrant requirement. See id. The plain view doctrine is one of those exceptions."

Lukaszewicz v. Boston, 409 Mass. 804 (19.proposition: Representative Massachusetts and other leading cases on negligence principles (illustrative; not an exhaustive list)
Lukaszewicz v. Boston, 409 Mass. 804 (19.support_reasoning: The case is a Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court decision applying core negligence doctrines, especially res ipsa loquitur, duty of care in premises liability, circumstantial proof of negligence and causation, and standards for sufficiency of the evidence to go to a jury. It cites and synthesizes multiple prior Massachusetts negligence authorities and discusses general negligence principles, making it representative for illustrating Massachusetts negligence law, even though it is not a comprehensive treatment of all negligence principles.
Lukaszewicz v. Boston, 409 Mass. 804 (19.relevant_excerpt: "When reviewing a ruling on a defendant's motion for directed verdict or motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict, we view the evidence in the light most favorable to the plaintiff... When an instrument under such control malfunctions, a jury may reasonably infer that the defendant failed to exercise reasonably the duty of care concomitant with the degree of control the defendant possessed... It is enough that the evidence makes it more probable than not that the defendant was negligent, and that that negligence was the cause of the injuries about which the plaintiff complains."

Vasil v. City of Boston, 432 Mass. 706 (.raw_text: Vasil v. City of Boston, 432 Mass. 706 (2000)
Vasil v. City of Boston, 432 Mass. 706 (.proposition: Representative Massachusetts and other leading cases on negligence principles (illustrative; not an exhaustive list)
Vasil v. City of Boston, 432 Mass. 706 (.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns Brady nondisclosure, prosecutorial misconduct, and ineffective assistance of counsel in a murder case; it does not analyze or apply general negligence principles, duty, breach, causation, or damages. It is a criminal procedure/constitutional rights case, not a representative Massachusetts negligence decision. Therefore it does not support the cited proposition about negligence principles.
Vasil v. City of Boston, 432 Mass. 706 (.relevant_excerpt:
We agree with the motion judge that the Commonwealth’s deliberate failure to disclose its agreement with Lewis, despite requests for such information, was of constitutional dimension. “
“[T]he suppression by the prosecution of evidence favorable to an accused upon request violates due process where the evidence is material either to guilt or to punishment.” Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83, 87 (1963). “Evidence tending to impeach the credibility of a key prosecution witness is clearly exculpatory.” Commonwealth v. Collins, 386 Mass. 1, 8 (1982).

Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 381 Mass. 1 (19.proposition: Representative Massachusetts and other leading cases on negligence principles (illustrative; not an exhaustive list)
Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 381 Mass. 1 (19.case_name: Curtiss-Wright Corp. v. Edel-Brown Tool & Die Co., Inc.
Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 381 Mass. 1 (19.support_reasoning: The proposition describes the case as a representative Massachusetts (and other leading) decision on negligence principles. Foley v. Polaroid in fact concerns trade secret misappropriation, estoppel, evidentiary discretion, equitable injunction standards, and calculation of damages in business torts, not negligence doctrine. While it applies the directed verdict/JNOV standard and discusses duties in the trade secret context, it does not serve as a leading or illustrative negligence case, so the citation does not accurately support the stated proposition.
Foley v. Polaroid Corp., 381 Mass. 1 (19.relevant_excerpt: “This court has recognized three acceptable methods of measuring damages in cases involving business torts such as the misappropriation of trade secrets: the defendant’s profits realized from his tortious conduct, the plaintiff’s lost profits, or a reasonable royalty. Jet Spray Cooler, Inc. v. Crampton, 377 Mass. 159, 169, 171 n.10 (1979).”

Souza v. Redden, 370 Mass. 352 (1976).proposition: Representative Massachusetts and other leading cases on negligence principles (illustrative; not an exhaustive list)
Souza v. Redden, 370 Mass. 352 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion in Souza v. Redden is a criminal case involving evidentiary rulings on photographs, admissibility and voluntariness of a confession, and review under G.L. c. 278, § 33E. It does not discuss civil negligence principles, standards of care, duty, breach, causation, or related doctrines. Therefore it cannot fairly be characterized as a representative or leading case on negligence principles in Massachusetts or elsewhere.
Souza v. Redden, 370 Mass. 352 (1976).relevant_excerpt: The judge charged the jury fully on all aspects of the two cases against the defendant, and there is no contention that there were any errors in the charge. The charge included instructions on the criminal responsibility of the defendant for his own conduct and the conditions under which he might be found responsible for the conduct of Bilodeau under the theory of concerted action or joint venture.

Lussier v. Grafton, 418 Mass. 123 (1994).proposition: Representative Massachusetts and other leading cases on negligence principles (illustrative; not an exhaustive list)
Lussier v. Grafton, 418 Mass. 123 (1994).support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about joinder, severance, and limits on cross-examination in joint trials; it does not discuss negligence or civil negligence principles at all. Therefore, it cannot serve as a representative Massachusetts or leading case on negligence principles, and using it for that proposition would be inaccurate.
Lussier v. Grafton, 418 Mass. 123 (1994).relevant_excerpt: We now turn to the merits of the appeal. When criminal charges against two or more individuals “arise out of the same criminal conduct,” Mass. R. Crim. P. 9 (b), 378 Mass. 859 (1979), it is presumed that those individuals will be tried together. “Joinder expedites the administration of justice, reduces the congestion of trial dockets, conserves judicial time, lessens the burden upon citizens who must sacrifice time and energy to serve upon juries, and avoids the necessity of recalling witnesses to successive trials.” Commonwealth v. Moran, 387 Mass. 644, 658 (1982).

Gath v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co.,.raw_text: Gath v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co., 9 Mass. App. Ct. 531 (1980)
Gath v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co.,.proposition: Representative Massachusetts and other leading cases on negligence principles (illustrative; not an exhaustive list)
Gath v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co.,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case focused on conspiracy, double jeopardy (multiple punishments for a single continuing conspiracy), and evidentiary/prosecutorial issues. It does not analyze or apply general negligence principles, duty, breach, causation, or damages. Thus it is not a representative Massachusetts case on negligence principles and does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
Gath v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co.,.relevant_excerpt: "2. Evidentiary matters. (a) Testimony about the fear felt by Griffin and Agostinelli at their encounters with Winter and Sperlinga was relevant... The victims’ fear confirms the capacity of the threats to create apprehension and is thus probative of the defendants’ intent to intimidate." (discussion of relevance and intent in a criminal extortion/conspiracy context, not negligence).
